claim: only 1 of f phyllis nelson 's single , don't stop the train make it to the us dance chart , but not the us hot 100 or us r&b
resp:
Here's my reasoning process:

1. First, I identify the claim which states that only one of f Phyllis Nelson's single, "Don't Stop The Train," made it to the US Dance chart but not the US Hot 100 or US R&B.
2. Next, I locate all relevant rows in the table corresponding to the singles of f Phyllis Nelson. There are three entries for her songs: "Don't Stop The Train" (1981), "Move Closer" (1985 re-issue), and "I Don't Know", "I Like You" (both 1985).
3. In each relevant row, I check the columns for the US Dance, US Hot 100, and US R&B charts.
4. For the year 1981, "Don't Stop The Train" is found in the US Dance chart (20th position) and not in the US Hot 100 or US R&B columns (they are empty). This matches one of the conditions in the claim.
5. For the years 1985, "Move Closer" (re-issue), "I Don't Know", and "I Like You" are all found in the table. None of these songs are in the US Dance chart; instead, they are positioned in the US Hot 100 or US R&B charts. This does not match the condition in the claim that none of her other singles made it to the US Dance chart.
6. Since "Don't Stop The Train" meets one of the conditions (made it to the US Dance chart but not the US Hot 100 or US R&B) and none of her other songs meet the condition (not in the US Dance chart), it is reasonable to conclude that only one of f Phyllis Nelson's singles, "Don't Stop The Train," made it to the US Dance chart but not the US Hot 100 or US R&B.
